If no salt value is specified in the ENCRYPTION-SALT attribute, no salt value is used.You can also use the GENERATE-PBE-SALT function to generate a salt value, which can help to ensure that the password key value is unique. If specified, this salt value is combined with the password value and hashed some number of times to generate a password-based encryption key (using the algorithm specified by the PBE-HASH-ALGORITHM attribute and the number of iterations specified by the PBE-KEY-ROUNDS attribute).

functions.name: GENERATE-PBE-SALT
functions.description: Generates a random salt value (a series of 8 bytes) to use in generating an encryption key, and returns the salt value as a RAW value. Using a salt value can help to ensure that a password key value is unique.

functions.name: GENERATE-RANDOM-KEY
functions.description: Generates a pseudorandom (rather than a truly random) series of bytes to use as an encryption key, and returns the key as a RAW value.

functions.name: GENERATE-UUID
functions.description: Generates a universally unique identifier (UUID), as a 16-byte RAW value.

functions.name: GET-BITS
functions.description: Interprets one or more consecutive bits in an integer variable or field as an ABL integer value and returns that value.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: An ABL integer variable.

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: A variable or expression that returns an integer. This parameter designates the position of the lowest-order bit of the bits that are to be interpreted as an integer. Bits are numbered from 1 through the length of an integer; with 1 being the low-order bit. If position is greater than the length of an integer, the AVM returns the Unknown value (?). If position is less than 1, the AVM generates a run-time error.

parameters.name: numbits
parameters.description: The number of bits to examine when generating the return value. If position plus numbits is greater than the length of an integer plus 1, the AVM generates a run-time error.

functions.name: GET-BYTE
functions.description: Returns the unsigned 1 byte value at the specified memory location as an INTEGER value.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: A function or variable that returns a RAW or MEMPTR value. If source is the Unknown value (?), GET-BYTE returns the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: An integer value greater than 0 that indicates the byte position where you want to find the information. If position is greater than the length of source, the AVM returns the Unknown value (?). If position is less than 1, the AVM generates a run-time error.

functions.name: GET-BYTE-ORDER
functions.description: Returns an INTEGER value indicating the byte order setting of a MEMPTR variable. This will be either the value provided by the last execution of SET-BYTE-ORDER with this MEMPTR variable, or HOST-BYTE-ORDER if SET-BYTE-ORDER has not been executed.

parameters.name: memptr
parameters.description: An expression that returns a MEMPTR.

functions.name: GET-BYTES
functions.description: Returns the specified number of bytes, from the specified location, into a RAW or MEMPTR variable.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: An expression that evaluates to a RAW or MEMPTR value indicating the source location. If source is the Unknown value (?), GET-BYTES returns the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: An integer value greater than 0 indicating the byte position of the first byte to get. If position is greater than the length of source, the AVM returns the Unknown value (?). If position is less than 1, the AVM generates a run-time error.

parameters.name: numbytes
parameters.description: An integer value greater than 0 indicating how many bytes to return as a RAW value. If position plus numbytes is greater than the size of source, the AVM returns the Unknown value (?).If the variable that accepts the returned data is a RAW variable and numbytes is greater than its length but less than or equal to 32K, the AVM increases the size of the variable to numbytes. If either the source location, source, or the variable that accepts the returned data is a RAW value, and numbytes is greater than 32K, the AVM generates a run-time error. If the variable that accepts the returned data is a MEMPTR variable and numbytes is greater than its length, the AVM generates a run-time error.

functions.name: GET-CLASS
functions.description: Returns the object reference for the Progress.Lang.Class instance associated with the specified class or interface type.

parameters.name: object-type-name
parameters.description: Specifies the type name of an ABL or .NET class or interface type, using the syntax described in the Type-name syntax reference entry. With an appropriate USING statement, you can also specify an unqualified class or interface name alone. If object-type-name is not the name of an existing ABL class that can be found on PROPATH or (for Windows) a .NET class that can be resolved based on the assemblies.xml file in use, a compiler error will result.

functions.name: GET-CODEPAGE
functions.description: The GET-CODEPAGE function returns the code page of a LONGCHAR variable or CLOB field.

parameters.name: large-char-object
parameters.description: The name of a LONGCHAR variable or CLOB field. If the specified LONGCHAR is empty and the code page was not fixed using the FIX-CODEPAGE statement, the AVM returns the Unknown value (?).

functions.name: GET-CODEPAGES
functions.description: The GET-CODEPAGES function returns a comma-delimited list of the code pages listed in convmap.cp or specified by the Conversion Map (-convmap) startup parameter for the current ABL session.

functions.name: GET-COLLATION
functions.description: The GET-COLLATION function returns the collation name for a CLOB field.

parameters.name: clob-field
parameters.description: A CLOB field name.

functions.name: GET-COLLATIONS
functions.description: The GET-COLLATIONS function returns a comma-delimited list of the collations either listed in convmap.cp or specified by the Conversion Map (-convmap) startup parameter for the specified code page.

parameters.name: codepage
parameters.description: A code page name. If there are no collations for the specified code page, the AVM returns the Unknown value (?).

functions.name: GET-DB-CLIENT
functions.description: Returns the handle to a copy of the sealed client-principal object that represents the user identity for the specified database connection.

parameters.name: db-exp
parameters.description: An optional character expression that evaluates to a case-insensitive logical or alias name of an OpenEdge RDBMS. This expression can be unspecified or evaluate to the Unknown value (?) only if there is a single OpenEdge database connection, in which case the client-principal object handle is returned for that connection.

functions.name: GET-DOUBLE
functions.description: Returns the 8-byte floating-point value at the specified memory location as a DECIMAL value.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: A function or variable that returns a RAW or MEMPTR value. If source is the Unknown value (?), GET-DOUBLE returns the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: An integer value greater than 0 that indicates the byte position where you want to find the information. If position is greater than the length of source, the AVM returns the Unknown value (?). If position is less than 1, the AVM generates a run-time error.

functions.name: GET-EFFECTIVE-TENANT-ID
functions.description: Returns the tenant ID of the effective tenant as an integer.

parameters.name: database-name
parameters.description: A character expression that evaluates to a logical database name or database alias. If no database is specified and more than one database is connected, the AVM raises an error. If the database name is not a valid name for a connected database, the AVM raises an error.

functions.name: GET-EFFECTIVE-TENANT-NAME
functions.description: Returns the name of the effective tenant as a character string.

parameters.name: database-name
parameters.description: A character expression that evaluates to a logical database name or database alias. If no database is specified and more than one database is connected, the AVM raises an error. If the database name is not a valid name for a connected database, the AVM raises an error.

functions.name: GET-FLOAT
functions.description: Returns the 4-byte floating-point value at the specified memory location as a DECIMAL value.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: A function or variable that returns a RAW or MEMPTR value. If source is the Unknown value (?), GET-FLOAT returns the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: An integer value greater than 0 that indicates the byte position where you want to find the information. If position is greater than the length of source, the AVM returns the Unknown value (?). If position is less than 1, the AVM generates a run-time error.

functions.name: GET-INT64
functions.description: Returns the signed 64-bit value at the specified memory location as an INT64 value.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: A function or variable that returns a RAW or MEMPTR value. If source is the Unknown value (?), GET-INT64 returns the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: An integer value greater than 0 that indicates the byte position where you want to find the information. If position is greater than the length of source, the AVM returns the Unknown value (?). If position is less than 1, the AVM generates a run-time error.

functions.name: GET-LONG
functions.description: Returns the signed 32-bit value at the specified memory location as an INTEGER value.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: A function or variable that returns a RAW or MEMPTR value. If source is the Unknown value (?), GET-LONG returns the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: An integer value greater than 0 that indicates the byte position where you want to find the information. If position is greater than the length of source, the AVM returns the Unknown value (?). If position is less than 1, the AVM generates a run-time error.

functions.name: GET-POINTER-VALUE
functions.description: Returns, as an INT64 value, the address of (or pointer to) the memory region associated with the specified MEMPTR variable. The returned value is based on whether the platform supports 64-bit pointers or 32-bit pointers. On a 32-bit platform, the value never gets bigger than 2GB.

parameters.name: memptr-var
parameters.description: A reference to a variable defined as MEMPTR. If the variable is uninitialized (has no associated memory region), the function returns 0.

functions.name: GET-SHORT
functions.description: Returns the signed 16-bit value at the specified memory location as an INTEGER value.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: A function or variable that returns a RAW or MEMPTR value. If source is the Unknown value (?), GET-SHORT returns the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: An integer value greater than 0 that indicates the byte position where you want to find the information. If position is greater than the length of source, the AVM returns the Unknown value (?). If position is less than 1, the AVM generates a run-time error.

functions.name: GET-SIZE
functions.description: Returns, as an INT64 value, the allocated byte size of the memory region associated with the specified MEMPTR variable.

parameters.name: memptr-var
parameters.description: A MEMPTR variable. If the variable is uninitialized (has no associated memory region), the function returns 0.

functions.name: GET-STRING
functions.description: Returns the null-terminated character string at the specified memory location as a CHARACTER value (not including the null terminator) or the number of bytes specified starting from the specified memory location as a CHARACTER value.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: A function or variable that returns a RAW or MEMPTR value. If source is the Unknown value (?), GET-STRING returns the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: An integer value greater than 0 that indicates the byte position where you want to find the information. If position is greater than the length of source, the AVM returns the Unknown value (?). If position is less than 1, the AVM generates a run-time error.

parameters.name: numbytes
parameters.description: An integer value greater than 0 that indicates how many bytes to convert into the CHARACTER value that is returned. If numbytes is not specified, or is -1, GET-STRING( ) returns all bytes until it encounters a NULL value.

functions.name: GET-UNSIGNED-LONG
functions.description: Returns the unsigned 32-bit value at the specified memory location as an INT64. This is analogous to the GET-UNSIGNED-SHORT function, except with a 32-bit value.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: A function or variable that returns a RAW or MEMPTR value. If source is the Unknown value (?), GET-UNSIGNED-LONG returns the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: An INTEGER or INT64 value greater than 0 that indicates the byte position where you want to find the information. If position is greater than the length of source, the AVM returns the Unknown value (?). If position is less than 1, the AVM generates a run-time error.

functions.name: GET-UNSIGNED-SHORT
functions.description: Returns the unsigned 16-bit value at the specified memory location as an INTEGER value.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: A function or variable that returns a RAW or MEMPTR value. If source is the Unknown value (?), GET-UNSIGNED-SHORT returns the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: An integer value greater than 0 that indicates the byte position where you want to find the information. If position is greater than the length of source, the AVM returns the Unknown value (?). If position is less than 1, the AVM generates a run-time error.

functions.name: GO-PENDING
functions.description: Returns a TRUE value if, within an EDITING phrase, an APPLY statement results in a GO action. The GO action is deferred until the end of the EDITING phrase.

functions.name: GUID
functions.description: Converts a universally unique identifier (UUID) value into a globally unique identifier (GUID) value. This function returns a GUID as a 36-character string value consisting of 32 hexadecimal digits (0 through 9 and A through F) and 4 hyphens formatted as follows (where X is a hexadecimal digit): XXXXXXXX—XXXX—XXXX—XXXX—XXXXXXXXXXXX.

parameters.name: UUID
parameters.description: An optional 16-byte raw UUID value to be converted. If the specified UUID is not exactly 16 bytes in length, the AVM returns the Unknown value (?). If not specified, the AVM generates a UUID and then converts it into a GUID.

functions.name: HANDLE
functions.description: Converts a string representation of a handle to a valid handle. If the string does not correlate to a valid handle in the session, the function returns 0.

parameters.name: handle-string
parameters.description: A string representation of a handle. Since handles are integer values, the string must contain only numeric characters.

functions.name: HEX-DECODE
functions.description: Converts a character string consisting of an even number of hexadecimal digits (0 through 9 and A through F) into a RAW value.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: A character expression containing the value you want to convert. If the expression does not contain an even number of hexadecimal digits, or it is the Unknown value (?), the result is the Unknown value (?). If the expression is a zero-length value, the result is a zero-length value.

functions.name: HEX-ENCODE
functions.description: Converts a RAW value into a character string consisting of an even number of hexadecimal digits (0 through 9 and A through F).

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: A RAW expression containing the value you want to convert. If the expression is the Unknown value (?), the result is the Unknown value (?). If the expression is a zero-length value, the result is a zero-length value.

functions.name: IF...THEN...ELSE
functions.description: Evaluates and returns one of two expressions, depending on the value of a specified condition.

parameters.name: condition
parameters.description: An expression whose value is logical (TRUE or FALSE).

parameters.name: expression1
parameters.description: A constant, field name, variable name, or expression. If the condition is TRUE, then the function returns this value.

parameters.name: expression2
parameters.description: A constant, field name, variable name, or expression whose value is of a data type that is compatible with the data type of expression1. If the condition is FALSE or the Unknown value (?), then the function returns this value.

functions.name: INDEX
functions.description: Returns an INTEGER value that indicates the position of a search string within a source string.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: A CHARACTER, LONGCHAR or MEMPTR expression.

parameters.name: searchString
parameters.description: A CHARACTER or LONGCHAR expression whose position you want to locate in source. If searchString does not exist within source, INDEX returns 0.

parameters.name: starting
parameters.description: An integer that specifies at which left-most position in the string to start the search. For example, INDEX("abcdefabcdef","abc",6) returns 7.

functions.name: INPUT
functions.description: References the value of a field in a frame. For example, if you use the PROMPT-FOR statement to get input from the user, PROMPT-FOR stores that information in the screen buffer. You can use the INPUT function to refer to that information.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: The name of the frame that contains the field named by the field argument. If you do not name a frame, the INPUT function starts with the current frame and searches outward until it finds the field you name with the field argument.

parameters.name: field
parameters.description: The name of a field or variable whose value is stored in the screen buffer. The specified field must be viewed as a fill-in or text widget.

functions.name: INT64
functions.description: Takes any data type and returns an INT64 value, if the conversion is possible. This function takes most common data types except for RAW and MEMPTR.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: A constant, field name, variable name, or expression whose value can be of any data type except for RAW and MEMPTR. The function behaves as described for the following data types:If the value of expression is a CHARACTER, it must be valid for conversion into a number (for example, "1.67" is valid, "1.x3" is not). If expression is an object reference (CLASS), the result is the ABL-generated ID for the class instance. If expression is a reference to an instance of an enum, the result is the underlying numeric value of that instance. If expression is a LOGICAL, the result is 0 if expression is FALSE and the result is 1 if expression is TRUE. If expression is a DATE, the result is the number of days from 1/1/4713 B.C. to that day. If expression is the Unknown value (?), the result is the Unknown value (?).

functions.name: INTEGER
functions.description: Converts an expression of any data type, with the exception of BLOB, CLOB, and RAW, to a 32-bit integer value of data type INTEGER, rounding that value if necessary.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: A constant, field name, variable name, or expression. The function behaves as described for the following data types: If the value of expression is a CHARACTER, it must be valid for conversion into a number (for example, "1.67" is valid, "1.x3" is not). If expression is an object reference (CLASS), the result is the ABL-generated ID for the class instance. If expression is a reference to an instance of an enum, the result is the underlying numeric value of that instance. Because the underlying numeric values of enum members are of type INT64, the function may raise an error if the value cannot be represented as an INTEGER. If expression is a LOGICAL, the result is 0 if expression is FALSE and the result is 1 if expression is TRUE. If expression is a DATE, the result is the number of days from 1/1/4713 B.C. to that day. If expression is the Unknown value (?), the result is the Unknown value (?).

functions.name: INTERVAL
functions.description: Returns the time interval between two DATE, DATETIME, or DATETIME-TZ values as an INT64 value.

parameters.name: datetime1
parameters.description: An expression whose value is a DATE, DATETIME, or DATETIME-TZ.

parameters.name: datetime2
parameters.description: An expression whose value is a DATE, DATETIME, or DATETIME-TZ.

parameters.name: interval-unit
parameters.description: A character constant, or a character expression that evaluates to one of the following time units: ‘years', ‘months', ‘weeks', ‘days', 'hours', ‘minutes', ‘seconds' or ‘milliseconds'. These values are case insensitive and might be singular.

functions.name: IS-ATTR-SPACE
functions.description: This function is supported only for backward compatibility.

functions.name: IS-CODEPAGE-FIXED
functions.description: Returns TRUE if the code page of the specified LONGCHAR variable is fixed; otherwise it returns FALSE.

parameters.name: longchar
parameters.description: The name of a LONGCHAR variable.

functions.name: IS-COLUMN-CODEPAGE
functions.description: Returns TRUE if the specified CLOB field is a COLUMN-CODEPAGE CLOB. Otherwise, it returns FALSE (that is, if the CLOB is a DBCODEPAGE CLOB or a TTCODEPAGE CLOB).

parameters.name: field
parameters.description: The name of a CLOB field.

functions.name: IS-DB-MULTI-TENANT
functions.description: Returns TRUE if a specified database is multi-tenant enabled, and returns FALSE if it is not.

parameters.name: database-name
parameters.description: A character expression that evaluates to a logical database name or database alias. If no database is specified and more than one database is connected, the AVM raises an error. If the database name is not a valid name for a connected database, the AVM raises an error.

functions.name: IS-LEAD-BYTE
functions.description: Returns TRUE if the first character of the string is the lead-byte of a multi-byte character. Returns FALSE if it is not.

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: A character expression (a constant, field name, variable name, or any combination of these) whose value is a character.

functions.name: ISO-DATE
functions.description: Returns a character representation of a DATE, DATETIME , or DATETIME-TZ that conforms to the ISO 8601 standard for date/time representations.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: An expression that evaluates to a DATE, DATETIME or DATETIME-TZ. The ISO-DATE function returns the character string in the standard ISO format of the data type. The following table lists the standard ISO formats for each data type. Standard ISO formats Data type ISO format DATE YYYY-MM-DD DATETIME YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.SSS DATETIME-TZ YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.SSS+HH:MM

functions.name: KBLABEL
functions.description: Returns the keyboard label (such as F1) of the key that performs a specified ABL function (such as GO).

parameters.name: key-function
parameters.description: An expression whose value is the name of the special ABL key function. See OpenEdge Programming Interfaces for possible values of key-name. If key-function is a constant, enclose it in quotation marks (""). See the same guide for a list of key functions and the corresponding standard keyboard keys.

functions.name: KEYCODE
functions.description: Evaluates a key label (such as F1) for a key in the predefined set of keyboard keys and returns the corresponding = key code (such as 301) as an INTEGER value. See OpenEdge Programming Interfaces for a list of key codes and key labels.

parameters.name: key-label
parameters.description: A constant, field name, variable name, or expression that evaluates to a character string that contains a key label. If key-label is a constant, enclose it in quotation marks (" ").

functions.name: KEYFUNCTION
functions.description: Evaluates an integer expression (such as 301) and returns a character string that is the function of the key associated with that integer expression (such as GO).

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: A constant, field name, variable name, or expression whose value is an integer key code.

functions.name: KEYLABEL
functions.description: Evaluates a key code (such as 301) and returns a character string that is the predefined keyboard label for that key (such as F1).

parameters.name: key-code
parameters.description: The key code of the key whose label you want to know. A special case of key-code is LASTKEY. See OpenEdge Programming Interfaces for a list of key codes and key labels.

functions.name: KEYWORD
functions.description: Returns a character value that indicates whether a string is an ABL reserved keyword.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: A constant, field name, variable name, or expression that results in a character string. If expression matches an ABL reserved keyword or valid abbreviation of a reserved keyword, the KEYWORD function returns the full keyword. If there is no match, the KEYWORD function returns the Unknown value (?).In some cases, the abbreviation for a keyword is also a keyword. For example, if expression is "def" (the abbreviation for DEFINE) or "col" (the abbreviation for COLUMN), the KEYWORD function returns the values "def" and "col", respectively. If you use the Run-time client, the KEYWORD function always returns the Unknown value (?).

functions.name: KEYWORD-ALL
functions.description: Returns a character value that indicates whether a string is an ABL keyword. This function returns all keywords and does not distinguish between reserved or unreserved keywords.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: A constant, field name, variable name, or expression that results in a character string. If expression matches an ABL keyword, whether reserved or unreserved or valid abbreviation of a keyword, the KEYWORD-ALL function returns the full keyword. If there is no match, the KEYWORD-ALL function returns the Unknown value (?).In some cases, the abbreviation for a keyword is also a keyword. For example, if expression is "def" (the abbreviation for DEFINE) or "col" (the abbreviation for COLUMN), the KEYWORD function returns the values "def" and "col", respectively. If you use the Run-time client, the KEYWORD-ALL function always returns the Unknown value (?).

functions.name: LAST
functions.description: Returns a TRUE value if the current iteration of a DO, FOR EACH, or REPEAT . . . BREAK block is the last iteration of that block.

parameters.name: break-group
parameters.description: The name of a field or expression you named in the block header with the BREAK BY option.

functions.name: LASTKEY
functions.description: Returns, as an INTEGER value, the integer key code of the most recent event read from the user (that is, from the keyboard or mouse) during an interaction with a procedure.

functions.name: LAST-OF
functions.description: Returns a TRUE value if the current iteration of a DO, FOR EACH, or REPEAT . . . BREAK block is the last iteration for a particular value of a break group.

parameters.name: break-group
parameters.description: The name of a field or expression you named in the block header with the BREAK BY option.

functions.name: LC
functions.description: Converts any uppercase characters in a CHARACTER or LONGCHAR expression to lowercase characters, and returns the result. The data type of the returned value matches the data type of the expression passed to the function.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: A constant, field name, variable name, or expression that results in a CHARACTER or LONGCHAR value.

functions.name: LDBNAME
functions.description: Returns the logical name of a database that is currently connected.

parameters.name: integer-expression
parameters.description: The sequence number of a database the ABL session is connected to. For example, LDBNAME(1) returns information on the first database the ABL session is connected to, LDBNAME(2) returns information on the second database the ABL session is connected to, etc. If you specify a sequence number that does not correspond to a database the ABL session is connected to, the LDBNAME function returns the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: logical-name
parameters.description: These forms of the LDBNAME function require a quoted character string or a character expression as a parameter. If the parameter is the logical name of a connected database or an alias of a connected database then the logical name is returned. Otherwise, the AVM returns the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: bufname
parameters.description: The name of a database table or buffer. The BUFFER option lets you determine the database a certain table belongs to without hard-coding the logical database name or alias.

functions.name: LEFT-TRIM
functions.description: Removes leading white space, or other specified characters, from a CHARACTER or LONGCHAR expression. The data type of the returned value matches the data type of the expression passed to the function.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: An expression (a constant, field name, variable name, or expression) whose value is a CHARACTER or LONGCHAR. If expression is a case-sensitive variable, the AVM performs a case-sensitive trim. If expression is a LONGCHAR, the result is in the same code page.

parameters.name: trim-chars
parameters.description: A character expression that specifies the characters to be trimmed from expression. If you do not specify trim-chars, the LEFT-TRIM function removes spaces, tabs, line feeds, and carriage returns.

functions.name: LENGTH
functions.description: Returns, as an INTEGER value, the number of characters, bytes, or columns in a string, an expression of type RAW, or a BLOB field.

parameters.name: exp
parameters.description: An expression that evaluates to a CHARACTER, LONGCHAR, INTEGER, LOGICAL, or CLOB type. If exp evaluates to an INTEGER or LOGICAL, the STRING function is used to first convert it to a character string before returning the LENGTH. For a LOGICAL, YES/TRUE returns 3 and NO/FALSE returns 2.

parameters.name: raw-exp
parameters.description: A function or variable name that returns a RAW value.

parameters.name: blob-field
parameters.description: An expression that evaluates to a BLOB field.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: A character expression that indicates whether you want the length of exp in character units, bytes, or columns. A double-byte character registers as one character unit. By default, the unit of measurement is character units.There are three valid types: "CHARACTER," "RAW," and "COLUMN." The expression "CHARACTER" indicates that the length is measured in characters, including double-byte characters. The expression "RAW" indicates that the length is measured in bytes. The expression "COLUMN" indicates that the length is measured in display or print character-columns. If you specify the type as a constant expression, ABL validates the type specification at compile time. If you specify the type as a non-constant expression, the AVM validates the type specification at run time. Note: The expression "COLUMN" is not valid for a LONGCHAR variable or a CLOB field.

functions.name: LIBRARY
functions.description: Parses a character string in the form path-name<<member-name>>, where path-name is the pathname of an ABL r-code library and member-name is the name of a file within the library, and returns the pathname of the library. The double angle brackets indicate that member-name is a file in a library. If the string is not in this form, the LIBRARY function returns the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: A character expression whose value is the pathname of a file in a library. In Windows, the pahtname cannot contain characters outside of the non-Unicode code page. See Internationalize ABL Applications for more information about Unicode and code pages.

functions.name: LINE-COUNTER
functions.description: Returns the current line number of paged output as an INTEGER value.

parameters.name: stream
parameters.description: Specifies the name of a stream. If you do not name a stream, the AVM uses the unnamed stream. For more information on streams, see this book's DEFINE STREAM statement reference entry and OpenEdge Programming Interfaces.

parameters.name: handle
parameters.description: Specifies the handle to a stream. If handle it is not a valid handle to a stream, the AVM generates a run-time error. Note that stream handles are not valid for the unnamed streams. See the topics on alternate I/O sources in OpenEdge Programming Interfaces for more information on streams and stream handles.

functions.name: LIST-EVENTS
functions.description: Returns a comma-separated list of the valid events for a specified object or widget.

parameters.name: handle
parameters.description: A handle to a valid object or widget. The function returns a list of the events that are valid for that object or widget.

parameters.name: platform
parameters.description: A character-string value that specifies a display type. Valid values are GUI and TTY. Some events are valid only on certain platforms. If you omit the platform parameter, the AVM uses the platform for the current session.

functions.name: LIST-QUERY-ATTRS
functions.description: Returns a comma-separated list of attributes and methods that are supported for an object or widget.

parameters.name: handle
parameters.description: A handle to a valid object or widget. The function returns a list of the attributes and methods that are supported for that object or widget.

functions.name: LIST-SET-ATTRS
functions.description: Returns a comma-separated list of attributes that can be set for an object or widget.

parameters.name: handle
parameters.description: A handle to a valid object or widget. The function returns a list of the attributes that can be set for that object or widget.

functions.name: LIST-WIDGETS
functions.description: Returns a comma-separated list of objects and widget types that respond to a specified event.

parameters.name: event-name
parameters.description: A character-string expression that evaluates to an event name.

parameters.name: platform
parameters.description: A character-string value that specifies a display type. Valid values are GUI and TTY. Some events are valid only on certain platforms. If you omit the platform parameter, the AVM uses the platform for the current session.

functions.name: LOCKED
functions.description: Returns a TRUE value in the following cases:

parameters.name: record
parameters.description: The name of a record or buffer. To use the LOCKED function with a record in a table defined for multiple databases, you must qualify the record's table name with the database name. See the record definition in the Record phrase reference entry for more information.

functions.name: LOG
functions.description: Calculates the logarithm of an expression using a specified base and returns that logarithm as a DECIMAL value.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: A decimal expression that you want the logarithm of.

parameters.name: base
parameters.description: A numeric expression that is the base you want to use. If you do not specify a base, LOG returns the natural logarithm, base (e). The base must be greater than 1.

functions.name: LOGICAL
functions.description: Converts any data type into the LOGICAL data type.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: An expression in the data type that you want to convert to logical.

parameters.name: char-expression-format
parameters.description: A character expression that evaluates to a valid logical format, such as "si/no", or "da/nyet". This argument is ignored unless expression is of CHARACTER type. Also, this argument is only needed if expression evaluates to something other than the usual TRUE or FALSE, or YES or NO values.

functions.name: LOOKUP
functions.description: Returns an INTEGER value giving the position of an expression in a list. Returns a 0 if the expression is not in the list.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: A constant, field name, variable name, or expression that results in a character value that you want to look up within a list of character expressions. If the value of expression is the Unknown value (?), the result of the LOOKUP function is the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: list
parameters.description: A character expression that contains the expression you name with the expression argument. Each entry in the list is separated with a delimiter. The list can be a variable of type CHARACTER or LONGCHAR. If list contains the Unknown value (?), LOOKUP returns the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: character
parameters.description: A delimiter you define for the list. The default is a comma. This allows the LOOKUP function to operate on non-comma-separated lists.

functions.name: MAXIMUM
functions.description: Compares two or more values and returns the largest value.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: A constant, field name, variable name, or expression. If there is a mixture of decimal and integer data types, decimal type is returned.

functions.name: MD5-DIGEST
functions.description: Hashes the specified data using the RSA Message Digest Hash Algorithm (MD5), and returns a 16-byte binary message digest value as a RAW value.

parameters.name: data-to-hash
parameters.description: The source data to hash. The data may be of type CHARACTER, LONGCHAR, RAW, or MEMPTR. If the data is a CHARACTER or LONGCHAR value, the AVM converts it to UTF-8 (which ensures a consistent value regardless of code page settings). To avoid this automatic conversion, specify a RAW or MEMPTR value.

parameters.name: hash-key
parameters.description: An optional key value to use in the hash operation. The key may be of type CHARACTER, LONGCHAR, RAW, or MEMPTR. If the key is a CHARACTER or LONGCHAR value, the AVM converts it to UTF-8 (which ensures a consistent value regardless of code page settings). To avoid this automatic conversion, specify a RAW or MEMPTR value. This key value is combined with the source data before the hash operation begins. If the hash-key value contains a null character, the null character is included in the hash operation.

functions.name: MEMBER
functions.description: Parses a reference to a member of an ABL r-code library and returns the simple member name.

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: A character expression (a constant, field name, variable or expression that results in a character value) whose value is the pathname of a file in an r-code library.

functions.name: MESSAGE-DIGEST
functions.description: Hashes any of several types of source data using the specified hashing algorithm, and returns a RAW message digest value whose size and security depends on the algorithm.

parameters.name: hash-algorithm
parameters.description: A character string that specifies the hashing algorithm to use to hash the data specified by data-to-hash. You can specify one of the following options, which are generally in the order of increased security and decreased performance: "MD5" — RSA Message Digest Hash Algorithm, which returns a 16-byte RAW binary message digest value. This is provided for backward compatibility only and should not be used in new development. "SHA-1" — United States Government Secure Hash Algorithm, which returns a RAW 20-byte binary message digest value. "SHA-256" — United States Government Secure Hash Algorithm, which returns a RAW 32-byte binary message digest value. "SHA-512" — United States Government Secure Hash Algorithm, which returns a RAW 64-byte binary message digest value. "HMAC-SHA-1" — United States Government HMAC (Hash-based Message Authentication Code) algorithm, which returns a RAW 20-byte binary message digest value. "HMAC-SHA-256" — United States Government HMAC (Hash-based Message Authentication Code) algorithm, which returns a RAW 32-byte binary message digest value. "HMAC-SHA-384" — United States Government HMAC (Hash-based Message Authentication Code) algorithm, which returns a RAW 48-byte binary message digest value. "HMAC-SHA-512" — United States Government HMAC (Hash-based Message Authentication Code) algorithm, which returns a RAW 64-byte binary message digest value.

parameters.name: data-to-hash
parameters.description: The source data to hash. The data may be of type CHARACTER, LONGCHAR, RAW, or MEMPTR. If the data is a CHARACTER or LONGCHAR value, the AVM converts it to UTF-8 (which ensures a consistent value regardless of code page settings). To avoid this automatic conversion, specify a RAW or MEMPTR value.

parameters.name: hash-key
parameters.description: A key value to use in the hash operation for the hashing algorithms. The key may be of type CHARACTER, LONGCHAR, RAW, or MEMPTR. If the key is a CHARACTER or LONGCHAR value, the AVM converts it to UTF-8 (which ensures a consistent value regardless of code page settings). To avoid this automatic conversion, specify a RAW or MEMPTR value. This key value is used along with the source data during the hash operation. For the HMAC algorithms, it is strongly recommended that you specify a hash key (preferably a randomly generated one). If hash-key is not specified it defaults to the empty string (""). If either data-to-hash or hash-key is the Unknown value (?), then the Unknown value (?) is returned from the function. If the hash-key value contains a null character, the null character is included in the hash operation.

functions.name: MESSAGE-LINES
functions.description: Returns, as an INTEGER value, the number of lines in the message area at the bottom of the window.

functions.name: MINIMUM
functions.description: Compares two or more values and returns the smallest.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: A constant, field name, variable name, or expression. If there is a mixture of decimal and integer data types, decimal type is returned.

functions.name: MONTH
functions.description: Evaluates a date expression and returns a month INTEGER value from 1 to 12, inclusive.

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: A date expression where you want a month value.

parameters.name: datetime-expression
parameters.description: An expression that evaluates to a DATETIME or DATETIME-TZ. The MONTH function returns the month of the date part of the DATETIME or DATETIME-TZ value.

functions.name: MTIME
functions.description: Returns an INTEGER value representing the time in milliseconds. If the MTIME function has no arguments, it returns the current number of milliseconds since midnight (similar to TIME, which returns seconds since midnight).

parameters.name: datetime-expression
parameters.description: An expression that evaluates to a DATETIME or DATETIME-TZ. The MTIME function returns the time portion of datetime-expression in milliseconds. If datetime-expression is a DATETIME-TZ, the MTIME function returns the local time relative to the time zone of the DATETIME-TZ value. For Example, a DATETIME-TZ field, fdt, is created in London (time zone UTC+00:00) with a value of May 5, 2002 at 7:15:03.002 am. MTIME(fdt) returns 26,103,002, regardless of the session's time zone.

functions.name: NEW (classes)
functions.description: Creates an instance of a class (object) and returns an object reference to that instance. You can use this object reference to access the PUBLIC data members, properties, and methods of the instance. For more information on object references, see the reference entry for a Class-based object reference.

parameters.name: object-type-name
parameters.description: Specifies the type name of the ABL or .NET class you want to instantiate. Specify a class type name using the syntax as described in the Type-name syntax reference entry. If object-type-name specifies a .NET object, it can be most any .NET class, with a few restrictions. For more information, see the Notes of this reference entry. The value of object-type-name is restricted to alphanumeric characters plus the symbols #, $, %, and _.If, without casting, you assign the NEW function value to a target data element, or pass the NEW function as input to a target routine parameter, object-type-name must specify one of the following classes: The same class type that is defined for the target A subclass of the class type that is defined for the target A class type that implements the interface type defined for the target If object-type-name specifies one of the following kinds of object types, ABL raises a compiler error: An interface type An abstract class type

parameters.name: parameter
parameters.description: Specifies zero or more parameters passed to a PUBLIC instance constructor that is defined for the class. You must provide the parameters identified by the specified constructor, matched with respect to number, data type, and mode. To invoke a constructor that is overloaded in the class, you must specify sufficient information for each parameter to disambiguate it from all other constructors in the class. Otherwise, ABL raises an error identifying the ambiguity.For information on the parameter passing syntax and disambiguating overloaded constructors, see the Parameter passing syntax reference entry. For information on defining a constructor for a class, see the CONSTRUCTOR statement reference entry.

functions.name: NEW (record buffers)
functions.description: Checks a record buffer and returns a TRUE value if the record in that buffer is newly created. If the record was read from the database, NEW returns a FALSE value.

parameters.name: record
parameters.description: The name of the record buffer you want to check with the NEW function.To use the NEW function with a record in a table defined for multiple databases, you must qualify the record's table name with the database name. See the record definition in the Record phrase reference entry for more information.

functions.name: NEXT-VALUE
functions.description: Returns the next INT64 value of a static sequence, incremented by the positive or negative value defined in the Data Dictionary.

parameters.name: sequence
parameters.description: An identifier that specifies the name of a sequence defined in the Data Dictionary.

parameters.name: logical-dbname
parameters.description: An identifier that specifies the logical name of the database in which the sequence is defined. The database must be connected. If multiple databases are connected, you can omit this parameter if you specify a sequence that is unique to one of the databases.tenant-id An integer expression that evaluates to the tenant ID of a regular tenant, including the default tenant (0). This option applies only to a multi-tenant sequence specified by sequence and is intended for access primarily by a super-tenant user. If you are a regular-tenant user and you specify tenant-id, the specified tenant must be the same as the tenant associated with the database connection identity for logical-dbname or the AVM raises a run-time error. If you are a super-tenant user and you do not specify tenant-id, the function assumes the effective tenant ID (GET-EFFECTIVE-TENANT-ID function). If the sequence specified by sequence is non-multi-tenant (a shared sequence in a multi-tenant database), and you specify tenant-id, the option is ignored.

functions.name: NORMALIZE
functions.description: Returns the normalized form of a character string based on the specified Unicode normalization form.

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The source string to normalize. The value may be of type CHARACTER or LONGCHAR.

functions.name: NOT ENTERED
functions.description: Returns a TRUE value if a frame field was not modified during the last INSERT, PROMPT-FOR, SET, or UPDATE statement.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: The frame name that contains the field named by the field argument. If you do not name a frame, the NOT ENTERED function starts with the current frame and searches outward until it finds the field you name with the field argument.

parameters.name: field
parameters.description: The name of the field or variable you are checking.

functions.name: NOW
functions.description: Returns the current system date, time, and time zone as a DATETIME-TZ value.

functions.name: NUM-ALIASES
functions.description: Returns an INTEGER value that represents the number of aliases defined. The NUM-ALIASES function uses no arguments.

functions.name: NUM-DBS
functions.description: Takes no arguments; returns the number of connected databases as an INTEGER value.

functions.name: NUM-ENTRIES
functions.description: Returns the number of elements in a list of character strings as an INTEGER value.

parameters.name: list
parameters.description: A character expression containing a list of character strings separated with a character delimiter. The list can be a variable of type CHARACTER or LONGCHAR. NUM-ENTRIES returns the number of elements in the list. Specifically, NUM-ENTRIES returns the number of delimiters plus 1, and it returns 0 if list equals the empty string ("").

parameters.name: character
parameters.description: A delimiter you define for the list. The default is a comma (,). This allows functions to operate on non-comma-separated lists. If you use an alphabetic character, this delimiter is case sensitive.

functions.name: NUM-RESULTS
functions.description: Returns, as an INTEGER value, the number of rows currently in the results list of a scrolling query. The results list is initialized when the query is opened. Depending on the query, the entire list is built immediately upon opening or it is gradually as needed.

parameters.name: query-name
parameters.description: A character expression that evaluates to the name of a currently open, scrolling query. If query-name does not resolve to the name of a query, or if the query is not open or not scrolling, then the function returns the Unknown value (?).Note: Searching for a query using a handle is more efficient than a character expression. The AVM resolves a character expression at run time by searching in the current routine for a static query with that name. If not found, the AVM searches the enclosing main procedure. If still not found, the AVM searches up through the calling programs of the current routine, and their main procedures. Since a handle uniquely identifies a query, no such search is required. Use the query object handle's NUM-RESULTS attribute to avoid a run-time search.

functions.name: OPSYS
functions.description: Identifies the operating system being used, so that a single version of a procedure can work differently under different operating systems. Returns the value of that operating system. Valid values are "UNIX" and "WIN32".

functions.name: OS-DRIVES
functions.description: (Windows only)

functions.name: OS-ERROR
functions.description: Returns, as an INTEGER value, an ABL error code that indicates whether an execution error occurred during the last OS-APPEND, OS-COPY, OS-CREATE-DIR, OS-DELETE, OS-RENAME or SAVE CACHE statement.

functions.name: OS-GETENV
functions.description: Returns a string that contains the value of the desired environment variable in the environment in which the ABL session is running.

parameters.name: environment-variable
parameters.description: The name of the environment variable whose value you want to find.

functions.name: PAGE-NUMBER
functions.description: Returns the page number of the output destination as an INTEGER value. If the output stream is not paged, PAGE-NUMBER returns a value of 0.

parameters.name: stream
parameters.description: The name of an output stream. If you do not name a stream, PAGE-NUMBER returns the page number of the default unnamed output stream.

parameters.name: handle
parameters.description: The handle to an output stream. If handle it is not a valid handle to a stream, the AVM generates a run-time error.

functions.name: PAGE-SIZE
functions.description: Returns the page size (lines per page) of an output destination as an INTEGER value. If the output stream is not paged, PAGE-SIZE returns a value of 0.

parameters.name: stream
parameters.description: The name of an output stream. If you do not name a stream, PAGE-SIZE returns the page size of the default unnamed output stream.

parameters.name: handle
parameters.description: The handle to an output stream. If handle it is not a valid handle to a stream, the AVM generates a run-time error.

functions.name: PDBNAME
functions.description: Returns the physical name of a currently connected database.

parameters.name: integer-expression
parameters.description: If the parameter supplied to PDBNAME is an integer expression, and there are, for example, three currently connected databases, then PDBNAME(1), PDBNAME(2), and PDBNAME(3) return their physical names. Also, continuing the same example of three connected databases, PDBNAME(4), PDBNAME(5), etc., return the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: logical-name
parameters.description: This form of the PDBNAME function requires a quoted character string or a character expression as a parameter. If the parameter is the logical name of a connected database or an alias of a connected database, then the physical name is returned. Otherwise, it returns the Unknown value (?).

functions.name: PROC-HANDLE
functions.description: Returns a value in the appropriate data type (usually INTEGER) that is a unique identifier for a stored procedure.

functions.name: PROC-STATUS
functions.description: Returns the return status from a stored procedure. The return status is an INTEGER value that indicates whether a stored procedure failed and why.

functions.name: PROCESS-ARCHITECTURE
functions.description: Identifies the bit value of the AVM process you are using at run time and returns this value as an INTEGER. Valid values are 32 for a 32-bit AVM and 64 for 64-bit AVM. For example, an application that uses a 32-bit Windows API through the DLL external procedure interface may need to pass different parameters to a function when running a 64-bit GUI client than when running a 32-bit GUI client. Using PROCESS-ARCHITECTURE, you can decide the parameters to pass.

functions.name: PROGRAM-NAME
functions.description: Returns the name of the calling program.

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The numeric argument. If n is 1, the name of the current program is returned. If n is 2, the name of the calling program is returned. If there is no calling program then you have reached the top of the call stack and the AVM returns the Unknown value (?).

functions.name: PROGRESS
functions.description: Returns one of the following character values which identifies the ABL product that is running: Full, Query or Run-time. Can also return COMPILE if you use the Developer's Toolkit, or COMPILE-ENCRYPT if you use the run-time Compiler.

functions.name: PROMSGS
functions.description: Returns the current value of the ABL PROMSGS variable.

functions.name: PROPATH
functions.description: Returns the current value of the PROPATH environment variable.

functions.name: PROVERSION
functions.description: Returns the version of ABL, or release of OpenEdge, you are running. You can also optionally retrieve additional release information, such as the service pack version number and the hot fix version number.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: An optional integer expression that identifies how much version information is returned, as follows:If the value of mode is either 0 or not specified, PROVERSION returns limited version information—the major version number, the minor version number, and, if applicable, the version tag. If the value of mode is 1, PROVERSION returns full version information—the major version number, the minor version number, the service pack number, the hot fix version number, the build number, and, if applicable, the version tag. If the value of mode is other than 1 or 0, a run-time error message is returned.

functions.name: QUERY-OFF-END
functions.description: Returns a LOGICAL value indicating whether the specified query is positioned at the end of its result list (either before the first record or after the last record).

parameters.name: query-name
parameters.description: A character expression that evaluates to the name of a currently open query. If query-name does not resolve to the name of a query, or if the query is not open, then the function returns the Unknown value (?).Note: Searching for a query using a handle is more efficient than a character expression. The AVM resolves a character expression at run time by searching in the current routine for a static query with that name. If not found, the AVM searches the enclosing main procedure. If still not found, the AVM searches up through the calling programs of the current routine, and their main procedures. Since a handle uniquely identifies a query, no such search is required. Use the query object handle's QUERY-OFF-END attribute to avoid a run-time search.

functions.name: QUOTER
functions.description: Converts the specified data type to CHARACTER and encloses the results in quotes when necessary.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: An expression in the data type that you want to convert to character and enclose with quotes.

parameters.name: quote-char
parameters.description: Either a single or double quote, enclosed in the opposite: "'" or '"'. The default is double quote. Passing ? for this argument results in double quotes.

parameters.name: null-string
parameters.description: The string you want for an unknown value: the word NULL or "" for example. The default is an unquoted question mark, which is the Unknown value (?).For example, the following code: DEFINE VARIABLE mychar As CHARACTER NO-UNDO INITIAL "Lift Line Skiing". ... qhandle:QUERY-PREPARE("FOR EACH Customer WHERE Customer.Name = " + QUOTER(mychar)) Would produce this prepare-string: FOR EACH Customer WHERE Customer.Name = "Lift Line Skiing".

functions.name: R-INDEX
functions.description: Returns an INTEGER value that indicates the position of the target string within the source string. In contrast to the INDEX function, R-INDEX performs the search from right to left.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: A constant, field name, variable name, or expression that results in a CHARACTER or LONGCHAR value.

parameters.name: target
parameters.description: A CHARACTER or LONGCHAR expression whose position you want to locate in source. If target does not exist within source, R-INDEX returns 0.If a starting parameter is not specified, then the search for the target pattern begins at the right-most character. Even though the search is started from the right, the target position is calculated from the left. For example, this code returns a 3 rather than a 2: R-INDEX("abcd" , "c")

parameters.name: starting
parameters.description: An integer that specifies the begin point for the search. The search is right-to-left and starts from the starting point. For example, this statement returns 1 R-INDEX("abcdefabcdef","abc",6).

functions.name: RANDOM
functions.description: Returns a random INTEGER value between two integers (inclusive).

parameters.name: low
parameters.description: An integer expression that is the lower of the two expressions you are supplying to the RANDOM function. This can be an INT64 value.

parameters.name: high
parameters.description: An integer expression that is the higher of the two expressions you are supplying to the RANDOM function. This can be an INT64 value.

functions.name: RAW
functions.description: (ORACLE only)

parameters.name: field
parameters.description: Any field from which you want to extract bytes.

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: An integer expression that indicates the position of the first byte you want to extract from field. The default value of position is 1.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: An integer expression that indicates the number of bytes you want to extract from field. If you do not use the length argument, RAW uses field from position to end.

functions.name: RECID
functions.description: Returns the unique internal identifier of the database record currently associated with the record buffer you name. This internal identifier has the data type RECID, a four-byte value that is supported by OpenEdge databases and some non-OpenEdge DataServers.

parameters.name: record
parameters.description: The name of the record whose RECID you want.To use the RECID function with a record in a table defined for multiple databases, you must qualify the record's table name with the database name. See the record definition in the Record phrase reference entry for more information.

functions.name: RECORD-LENGTH
functions.description: Returns the length of a record in a buffer as an INTEGER value.

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: A database buffer containing a record.

functions.name: REJECTED
functions.description: Returns the current REJECTED attribute setting for a ProDataSet temp-table buffer.

parameters.name: buffer-name
parameters.description: The name of a ProDataSet temp-table buffer.

functions.name: REPLACE
functions.description: Returns a string with specified substring replacements. The data type of the returned value matches the data type of the expression passed to the function.

parameters.name: source-string
parameters.description: Specifies the base string to make replacements in. The source-string parameter can be any expression that evaluates to a string or a LONGCHAR. The REPLACE function does not change the value of source-string itself; the function returns the string with replacements.

parameters.name: from-string
parameters.description: Specifies the substring to replace. The from-string parameter can be any expression that evaluates to a string or a LONGCHAR. Each occurrence of from-string within source-string is replaced.

parameters.name: to-string
parameters.description: Specifies the replacement substring. The to-string parameter can be any expression that evaluates to a string or a LONGCHAR. Each occurrence of from-string in source-string is replaced by to-string.

functions.name: RETRY
functions.description: Returns a TRUE value if the current block is being reprocessed after a previous UNDO, RETRY.

functions.name: RETURN-VALUE
functions.description: Provides a character string value returned by the most recently executed RETURN statement of a local or remote procedure, trigger block, user-defined function, method of a class, class constructor, or property accessor.

functions.name: RGB-VALUE
functions.description: Returns an INTEGER value that represents a combination of a red, green, and blue color value. This function allows you to define an arbitrary color, expanding beyond those colors defined in the color table.

parameters.name: redval
parameters.description: Identifies red, green, and blue color values which can be combined to define a unique color value.

functions.name: RIGHT-TRIM
functions.description: Removes trailing white space, or other specified characters, from a CHARACTER or LONGCHAR expression. The data type of the returned value matches the data type of the expression passed to the function.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: An expression (a constant, field name, variable name, or expression) whose value is a CHARACTER or LONGCHAR. If expression is a case-sensitive variable, the AVM performs a case-sensitive trim. If expression is a LONGCHAR, the result is in the same code page.

parameters.name: trim-chars
parameters.description: A character expression that specifies the characters to trim from expression. If you do not specify trim-chars, the RIGHT-TRIM function removes spaces, tabs, line feeds, and carriage returns.

functions.name: ROUND
functions.description: Rounds a decimal expression to a specified number of places after the decimal point.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: A decimal expression.

parameters.name: precision
parameters.description: A non-negative integer expression whose value is the number of places you want in the decimal result of the ROUND function.

functions.name: ROW-STATE
functions.description: Returns an INTEGER value that represents the current change state of a static ProDataSet temp-table buffer.

parameters.name: buffer-name
parameters.description: The name of a ProDataSet temp-table buffer (preferably a before-image temp-table buffer).

functions.name: ROWID
functions.description: Returns the unique internal identifier of the database record currently associated with the record buffer you name. This internal identifier has the data type ROWID, which is supported for OpenEdge and all other DataServer databases.

parameters.name: record
parameters.description: The name of the record whose ROWID you want.To use the ROWID function with a record in a table defined for multiple databases, you must qualify the record's table name with the database name. See the record definition in the Record phrase reference entry for more information.

functions.name: SCREEN-LINES
functions.description: Returns, as an INTEGER value, the number of lines you can use to display frames. This value omits the space used by the message area and status area.

functions.name: SDBNAME
functions.description: Accepts an integer expression or a character expression as a parameter. If the parameter resolves to a currently connected non-OpenEdge database then the SDBNAME function returns the logical name of the schema holder database containing the non-OpenEdge schema. If the parameter resolves to a currently connected OpenEdge database, the SDBNAME function returns the logical name of this database.

parameters.name: integer-expression
parameters.description: If the parameter supplied to SDBNAME is an integer expression, and there are, for example, three connected databases, then SDBNAME(1), SDBNAME(2), and SDBNAME(3) return the logical names of their respective schema holder databases. Also, if there are three connected databases, SDBNAME(4), SDBNAME(5), etc., return the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: logical-name
parameters.description: These forms of the SDBNAME function require a quoted character string or a character expression as a parameter. If the parameter is the logical name of a connected database or an alias of a connected database, then the logical name of the schema holder database is returned according to the rule. Otherwise, SDBNAME returns the Unknown value (?).

functions.name: SEARCH
functions.description: Searches the directories and libraries defined in the PROPATH environment variable for a file. The SEARCH function returns the full pathname of the file unless it is found in your current working directory. If SEARCH does not find the file, it returns the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: opsys-file
parameters.description: A character expression whose value is the name of the file you want to find. The name can include a complete or partial directory path. If opsys-file is a constant string, you must enclose it in quotation marks (" "). The value of opsys-file must be no more than 255 characters long. The filename can contain Unicode characters. See Internationalize ABL Applications for more information about Unicode.

functions.name: SEEK
functions.description: Returns the offset of the file pointer in a text file as an INT64 value. You define a procedure variable to hold the offset value and later position the file to that offset.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: If you specify SEEK (name), the SEEK function returns the current position of the file pointer in the named input or output stream. The stream must be associated with an open file, or SEEK returns the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: handle
parameters.description: If you specify the handle to a stream, the SEEK function returns the current position of the file pointer in the stream. If handle it is not a valid handle to a stream, the AVM generates a run-time error.

functions.name: SET-DB-CLIENT
functions.description: Sets the user identity for a specified connected OpenEdge database using an unsealed or a sealed client-principal object.

parameters.name: client-principal-handle
parameters.description: A handle to a client-principal object. If the client-principal object is unsealed, it must be initialized with the attribute values required by the SEAL( ) method in addition to any PRIMARY-PASSPHRASE attribute value required to authenticate the asserted user identity. If the object is sealed, it must be sealed with a domain access code that is the same as the access code configured for the user's domain stored in the domain registry trusted by the specified database connection. If this parameter is set to the Unknown value (?), the current identity of affected database connections remains unchanged, and the function unlocks and allows the connection identity to be set using the SET-CLIENT( ) method, as described for the setting of database parameters.

parameters.name: integer-expression
parameters.description: Specifies a database connection on which to set the identity as follows: integer-expression The sequence number of a connected OpenEdge database for which to set the user identity. For example, SET-DB-CLIENT(hCP, 1) sets the user identity associated with the specified client-principal object for the first database connection, SET-DB-CLIENT(hCP, 2) sets the user identity for the second database connection, and so on. If you specify a sequence number that does not correspond to a connected database, the function returns FALSE. logical-name | alias The logical name or alias of a connected OpenEdge database for which to set the user identity. These forms require a quoted character string or a character expression. If you specify a logical name or alias that does not correspond to a connected database, the function returns FALSE. If you pass a valid option to identify an OpenEdge database connection, the function operates on that OpenEdge database connection as follows: If the LOGIN-STATE attribute on the client-principal object is set to "INITIAL", the function performs a user authentication operation, and if successful, sets user identity for the database connection, If the LOGIN-STATE attribute on the client-principal object is set to "LOGIN", the function performs a validation (SSO) of the user identity, and if successful, sets the user identity for the database connection. If client-principal-handle is the Unknown value (?), the current connection identity remains unchanged, and the function removes the SECURITY-POLICY:SET-CLIENT( ) method lockout on the database connection. If you do not pass an option to identify the specific database connection or you specify the Unknown value (?), the function operates on all OpenEdge database connections as follows: If the LOGIN-STATE attribute on the client-principal object is set to "INITIAL", the function performs a user authentication operation for the first OpenEdge database connection, and if the authentication is successful, the function: Sets that database connection's user identity. With the client-principal LOGIN-STATE attribute set to "LOGIN", performs an SSO operation to validate and (if successful) set the user identity for each remaining OpenEdge database connection in the ABL session. If the LOGIN-STATE attribute on the client-principal object is set to "LOGIN", the function performs an SSO operation to validate and (if successful) set the user identity for each OpenEdge database connection in the ABL session. If client-principal-handle is the Unknown value (?), the current identity remains unchanged for all OpenEdge databases connections, and the function removes the SECURITY-POLICY:SET-CLIENT( ) method lockout on all the connections.

parameters.name: integer-expression
parameters.description: The sequence number of a connected OpenEdge database for which to set the user identity. For example, SET-DB-CLIENT(hCP, 1) sets the user identity associated with the specified client-principal object for the first database connection, SET-DB-CLIENT(hCP, 2) sets the user identity for the second database connection, and so on. If you specify a sequence number that does not correspond to a connected database, the function returns FALSE.

parameters.name: logical-name
parameters.description: The logical name or alias of a connected OpenEdge database for which to set the user identity. These forms require a quoted character string or a character expression. If you specify a logical name or alias that does not correspond to a connected database, the function returns FALSE.

functions.name: SET-EFFECTIVE-TENANT
functions.description: Sets the effective tenancy of a multi-tenant database connection for a super-tenant user. A super tenant has no real tenancy of its own, but can act as if it is a particular regular tenant without the user having to authenticate a new connection identity that has that particular tenancy. Therefore, the effective tenancy is the acting regular tenancy of a super tenant.

parameters.name: tenant-expression
parameters.description: An integer or character string expression. If tenant-expression evaluates to an integer, the value must be a valid tenant ID for a regular or default tenant. If tenant-expression evaluates to a character string, the value must be a valid tenant name for a regular or default tenant. Otherwise, the statement raises ERROR.

parameters.name: database-name
parameters.description: A character expression that evaluates to a logical database name or database alias. If no database is specified and more than one database is connected, the AVM raises an error. If the database name is not a valid name for a connected database, the AVM raises an error.

functions.name: SETUSERID
functions.description: Authenticates a user identity for a specified database connection, verifying that the user ID and password supplied to the SETUSERID function match a user account in the _User table of the database. (This restriction does not apply to authentication with an STS-enabled database. See notes below for more information.) If they match, the database connection is set to the specified user identity and the function returns a TRUE value. If the database is multi-tenant, is also sets the user's tenancy.

parameters.name: userid
parameters.description: A literal value, field name, variable name, or expression that results in a character value that represents the user's user ID. If you use a literal value, you must enclose it in quotation marks (""). If the user is defined in a non-default domain, this value must be a fully qualified user ID, including both the non-qualified user ID and domain separated by a domain delimiter (@). If the user is defined in the default (blank) domain, only a non-qualified user ID (without a domain delimiter) must be specified. For more information on specifying a fully qualified user ID, see the reference entry for the QUALIFIED-USER-ID attribute. Note: The default blank domain provides backward compatibility with OpenEdge releases that do not support domains as part of a user's identity.

parameters.name: password
parameters.description: A literal value, field name, variable name, or other character expression that results in a character value that represents the user's password. If you use a literal value, you must enclose it in quotation marks (""). Alternatively, you can encrypt the password using the ENCRYPT-AUDIT-MAC-KEY( ) method. For more information, see the topics on encrypted passwords in OpenEdge Programming Interfaces.

parameters.name: logical-dbname
parameters.description: The logical name of the database on whose connection you want to check and set the user identity. The logical database name must be a character string enclosed in quotes, or a character expression. If you do not specify this argument, the compiler inserts the name of the database that is connected when the procedure is compiled. If you omit this argument and more than one database is connected, ABL raises an error.

functions.name: SHA1-DIGEST
functions.description: Hashes the specified data using the United States Government Secure Hash Algorithm (SHA-1), and returns a 20-byte binary message digest value as a RAW value.

parameters.name: data-to-hash
parameters.description: The source data to hash. The data may be of type CHARACTER, LONGCHAR, RAW, or MEMPTR. If the data is a CHARACTER or LONGCHAR value, the AVM converts it to UTF-8 (which ensures a consistent value regardless of code page settings). To avoid this automatic conversion, specify a RAW or MEMPTR value.

parameters.name: hash-key
parameters.description: An optional key value to use in the hash operation. The key may be of type CHARACTER, LONGCHAR, RAW, or MEMPTR. If the key is a CHARACTER or LONGCHAR value, the AVM converts it to UTF-8 (which ensures a consistent value regardless of code page settings). To avoid this automatic conversion, specify a RAW or MEMPTR value. This key value is combined with the source data before the hash operation begins. If the hash-key value contains a null character, the null character is included in the hash operation.

functions.name: SQRT
functions.description: Returns the square root (as a DECIMAL value) of an expression you specify.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: A numeric expression. If the value of the expression is negative, SQRT returns the Unknown value (?).

functions.name: SSL-SERVER-NAME
functions.description: Returns the digital certificate subject name for an OpenEdge database connected via SSL. If a database connection does not exist or the connection is not using SSL, this function returns the Unknown value (?).

parameters.name: logical-database-name
parameters.description: A quoted character string or character expression that specifies the database by its logical name.

functions.name: STRING
functions.description: Converts a value of any data type into a character value.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: An expression of any data type that you want to convert to a character value.

parameters.name: format
parameters.description: The format you want to use for the new character value. This format must be appropriate to the data type of source. If you do not use this argument, ABL uses the EXPORT format for all data types (except DATETIME and DATETIME-TZ, in which case it uses the default display format). This is useful if you want to produce left-justified numbers. For information on data display formats, see ABL Essentials.

functions.name: SUBSTITUTE
functions.description: Returns a character string that is made up of a base string plus the substitution of arguments in the string. It allows you to use a single string in place of concatenated strings.
