The function is designed to simplify the task of translating an application from one language to another and is similar to the sprintf function in the C programming language. The data type returned reflects the data type used in its input parameter. For example, if the input parameter is a LONGCHAR, then the function returns a LONGCHAR; if the input parameter is a CHARACTER, then the function returns a CHARACTER.

parameters.name: base-string
parameters.description: A CHARACTER or LONGCHAR variable optionally containing substitution parameters of the form &n, where n is an integer between 1 and 9, inclusive.

parameters.name: arg
parameters.description: A constant, field name, variable, or expression that results in a CHARACTER or LONGCHAR value. These argument values replace substitution parameters in base-string.

functions.name: SUBSTRING
functions.description: Extracts a portion of a character string from a field or variable.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: A CHARACTER or LONGCHAR expression from which you want to extract characters or bytes.

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: An integer expression that indicates the position of the first character you want to extract from source.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: An integer expression that indicates the number of characters you want to extract from source. If you do not use the length argument or specify -1 as the length, SUBSTRING uses the remainder of the string from the specified position.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: A CHARACTER expression that directs ABL to interpret the specified position and length values as character units, bytes, or columns. A double-byte character registers as one character unit. By default, ABL interprets the specified position and length values as character units. There are four valid types: "CHARACTER," "FIXED," "COLUMN," and "RAW." The expression "CHARACTER" specifies character units. The expression "FIXED" specifies that position is in character units and the length is in bytes, but directs SUBSTRING to yield only whole characters. That is, if the last byte or bytes represent part of, but not all of, a multi-byte character, these bytes are excluded. The expression "COLUMN" specifies display or print character-columns. The expression "RAW" specifies bytes. If you specify the type as a constant expression, ABL validates the type specification at compile time. If you specify the type as a non-constant expression, the AVM validates the type specification at run time. Note: If source is a LONGCHAR expression, "CHARACTER" is the only valid type and the default type.

functions.name: SUPER
functions.description: Runs the super procedure version of the current user-defined function.

parameters.name: parameter
parameters.description: A parameter of the super version of the current user-defined function. These parameters must have the same signature (number of parameters, and type and mode of each) as the parameters of the current user-defined function. You can, however, adjust a parameter's value. For the parameter syntax, see the Parameter definition syntax reference entry. If a user-defined function cannot be located in any super procedure, the AVM generates the following error message: SUPER version of user-defined function name invoked but could not be found Errors are stored in the ERROR-STATUS handle when NO-ERROR is specified.

functions.name: TENANT-ID
functions.description: Returns the tenant ID (as an integer) of the real tenant associated with a database connection.

parameters.name: database-name
parameters.description: A character expression that evaluates to a logical database name or database alias. If the database is not enabled for multi-tenancy, the function returns zero (0). If no database is specified and more than one database is connected, the AVM raises an error. If the database name is not a valid name for a connected database, the AVM raises an error.

functions.name: TENANT-NAME
functions.description: Returns the name (as a character string) of the real tenant associated with a database connection.

parameters.name: database-name
parameters.description: A character expression that evaluates to a logical database name or database alias. If the database is not enabled for multi-tenancy, the function returns the empty string (""). If no database is specified and more than one database is connected, the AVM raises an error. If the database name is not a valid name for a connected database, the AVM raises an error.

functions.name: TENANT-NAME-TO-ID
functions.description: Returns the tenant ID associated with an input tenant name.

parameters.name: tenant-name
parameters.description: A character expression that evaluates to the name of a tenant.

parameters.name: database-name
parameters.description: A character expression that evaluates to a logical database name or database alias. If no database is specified and more than one database is connected, the AVM raises an error. If the database name is not a valid name for a connected database, the AVM raises an error.

functions.name: TERMINAL
functions.description: In Windows, in graphical interfaces, TERMINAL returns WIN3. In Windows, in character interfaces, TERMINAL returns CO80, BW80, or MONO, depending on the monitor type. On UNIX, TERMINAL returns the value of the $TERM environment variable. In batch mode, TERMINAL returns a null string.

functions.name: TIME
functions.description: Returns an INTEGER value representing the time as the number of seconds since midnight. Use this function together with the STRING function to produce the time in hours, minutes, and seconds.

functions.name: TIMEZONE
functions.description: Returns an INTEGER value representing the time zone offset from Coordinated Universal Time (UTC), in minutes. Use this function together with the STRING function to produce the time in hours, minutes, and seconds.

parameters.name: datetime-tz-expression
parameters.description: An expression whose value is a DATETIME-TZ.

parameters.name: char-expression
parameters.description: A character expression representing the time zone offset. The format of the expression must be +HH:MM. If the TIMEZONE function has no arguments, it returns the client or server machine that serves as the time source for applications running during the ABL session (specified by the TIME-SOURCE attribute).

functions.name: TODAY
functions.description: Returns the current system date.

functions.name: TO-ROWID
functions.description: Converts a string representation of a ROWID to a valid ROWID value.

parameters.name: rowid-string
parameters.description: A string representation of a ROWID. Since ROWID values are a variable sequence of hexadecimal digits, rowid-string must be in the form "0xhex-digits", where hex-digits is any string of characters from 0 through 9 and A through F.

functions.name: TRANSACTION
functions.description: Returns a LOGICAL value that indicates whether a transaction is currently active.

functions.name: TRIM
functions.description: Removes leading and trailing white space, or other specified characters, from a CHARACTER or LONGCHAR expression. The data type of the returned value matches the data type of the expression passed to the function.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: An expression (a constant, field name, variable name, or expression) whose value is a CHARACTER or LONGCHAR. If expression is a case-sensitive variable, the AVM performs a case-sensitive trim. If expression is a LONGCHAR, the result is in the same code page.

parameters.name: trim-chars
parameters.description: A character expression that specifies the characters to trim from expression. If you do not specify trim-chars, the TRIM function removes spaces, tabs, line feeds, and carriage returns.

functions.name: TRUNCATE
functions.description: Truncates a decimal expression to a specified number of decimal places, returning a decimal value.

parameters.name: expression
parameters.description: A decimal expression that you want to truncate.

parameters.name: decimal-places
parameters.description: A non-negative integer expression that indicates the number of decimal places for a truncated expression.

functions.name: TYPE-OF
functions.description: Verifies that the class instance to which the specified object reference points is an instance of the specified object type, inherits from the specified super class, or implements the specified interface. If the object reference points to an instance of the specified type, the function returns TRUE. Otherwise, it returns FALSE.

functions.name: UNBOX
functions.description: (Windows only; GUI for .NET only)

parameters.name: object-reference
parameters.description: Specifies an object reference to a boxed .NET primitive value (System.Object) or to a one-dimensional .NET array object. For a list of the .NET primitive types that a System.Object can box, see Table 4. If object-reference points to a boxed .NET primitive value, the function returns a value of the ABL primitive type that implicitly maps to the boxed .NET type. If object-reference points to a one-dimensional .NET array object, the function returns a copy of the elements contained by the .NET array as an ABL array. If these elements are .NET mapped object types, the returned ABL array contains elements of the corresponding ABL primitive type. Otherwise, the ABL array contains object reference elements of the actual object type contained by the input .NET array.

functions.name: USERID
functions.description: Returns a character string representing the user ID for the specified database connection identity.

parameters.name: logical-dbname
parameters.description: The logical name of the database from whose connection identity you want to retrieve the user ID. The logical database name must be a character string enclosed in quotes, or a character expression. If you do not specify this argument, the compiler inserts the name of the database that is connected when the procedure is compiled. If you omit this argument and more than one database is connected, ABL raises an error.

functions.name: VALID-EVENT
functions.description: Verifies whether a specified event is valid for a specified widget. For each type of widget, only certain events are valid. The function returns a value (TRUE/FALSE).

parameters.name: handle
parameters.description: An expression that produces a value of type HANDLE. The value must be the handle of a valid widget.

parameters.name: event-name
parameters.description: A character-string expression that evaluates to the name of an event.

parameters.name: platform
parameters.description: A character-string expression that evaluates to the name of a platform type: GUI or TTY.

functions.name: VALID-HANDLE
functions.description: Verifies that a handle is valid.

parameters.name: handle
parameters.description: An expression that evaluates to a value of type HANDLE. If the handle represents an object that is currently valid, VALID-HANDLE returns TRUE. If the handle is no longer valid (if, for example, some procedure deleted the object), the function returns FALSE.

functions.name: VALID-OBJECT
functions.description: Verifies that an object reference points to a valid ABL or .NET class-based object instance or an ABL handle-based object. If the object reference represents an object that is currently valid, the function returns TRUE. If the object reference is no longer valid (for example, it was garbage collected or explicitly deleted), the function returns FALSE.

parameters.name: handle
parameters.description: A handle to an ABL handle-based object. The handle argument must be a variable of type HANDLE and must contain a valid handle. When used with a handle-based object, VALID-OBJECT works in the same way as the VALID-HANDLE function.

parameters.name: object-reference
parameters.description: An object reference defined for an ABL or .NET object type. For more information, see the Class-based object reference reference entry.

functions.name: WEEKDAY
functions.description: Evaluates a date expression and returns the day of the week as an INTEGER value from 1 (Sunday) to 7 (Saturday) for that date.

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: A date expression for which you want the day of the week.

parameters.name: datetime-expression
parameters.description: An expression that evaluates to a DATETIME or DATETIME-TZ. The WEEKDAY function returns the weekday of the date part of the DATETIME or DATETIME-TZ value.

functions.name: WIDGET-HANDLE
functions.description: This function is supported only for backward compatibility. Use the HANDLE function instead.

parameters.name: handle-string
parameters.description: A string representation of a handle. Since handles are integer values, the string must contain only numeric characters.

functions.name: YEAR
functions.description: Evaluates a date expression and returns the year value of that date, including the century, as an INTEGER value.

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: A date expression for which you want to determine the year.

parameters.name: datetime-expression
parameters.description: An expression that evaluates to a DATETIME or DATETIME-TZ. The YEAR function returns the year of the date part of the DATETIME or DATETIME-TZ value.
